dt: {bc}to raise from a lower to a higher position {bc}{sx|elevate||}
{bc}to put an end to (a blockade or siege) by withdrawing or causing the withdrawal of investing forces
{bc}to take up (something, such as a root crop or transplants) from the ground
{bc}to move from one place to another (as by aircraft) {bc}{sx|transport||}
{bc}to take up (a fingerprint) from a surface

pt: {sc}lift{/sc} {sc}raise{/sc} {sc}rear{/sc} {sc}elevate{/sc} {sc}hoist{/sc} {sc}heave{/sc} {sc}boost{/sc} mean to move from a lower to a higher place or position. {sc}lift{/sc} usually implies exerting effort to overcome resistance of weight.
{sc}raise{/sc} carries a stronger implication of bringing up to the vertical or to a high position.
{sc}rear{/sc} may add an element of suddenness to {sc}raise{/sc}.

pt.t: suddenly {it}reared{/it} itself up on its hind legs

pt: {sc}elevate{/sc} may replace {sc}lift{/sc} or {sc}raise{/sc} especially when exalting or enhancing is implied.
{sc}hoist{/sc} implies lifting something heavy especially by mechanical means.
{sc}heave{/sc} implies lifting and throwing with great effort or strain.
{sc}boost{/sc} suggests assisting to climb or advance by a push.

et: Middle English, from Old Norse {it}lypta{/it}; akin to Old English {it}lyft{/it} air {ma}{mat|loft|}{/ma}
shortdef: to raise from a lower to a higher position : elevate
to raise in rank or condition
to raise in rate or amount

dt: {bc}the amount that may be lifted at one time {bc}{sx|load||}
{bc}the action or an instance of lifting
{bc}the action or an instance of rising
{bc}the lifting up (as of a dancer) usually by a partner
{bc}a device (such as a handle or latch) for lifting
{bc}a layer in the heel of a shoe
{bc}a rise or advance in position or condition
{bc}the distance or extent to which something rises
{bc}an apparatus or machine used for hoisting: such as
{bc}a set of pumps used in a mine
{bc}an apparatus for raising an automobile (as for repair)

{bc}the component of the total aerodynamic force acting on an airplane or airfoil that is perpendicular to the relative wind and that for an airplane constitutes the upward force that opposes the pull of gravity
{bc}an updraft that can be used to increase altitude (as of a sailplane)
{bc}an organized movement of people, equipment, or supplies by some form of transportation
{bc}plastic surgery on a part of the body typically to improve a drooping or sagging appearance especially by reducing excess skin and fat

shortdef: the amount that may be lifted at one time : load
the action or an instance of lifting
the action or an instance of rising

dt: {bc}a small truck for lifting and transporting loads

shortdef: a small truck for lifting and transporting loads

dt: {bc}to make an effort to do something

dt.t: I have so many chores to do, and my sister won't {it}lift a finger{/it} to help me.
He never {it}lifted a finger{/it} to try to improve his failing grades.

shortdef: to make an effort to do something —usually used in negative statements

dt: {bc}to pick up (something) in order to move it to a lower position

dt.t: I had to {it}lift{/it} the box {it}down{/it} from the top shelf to the floor.

shortdef: to pick up (something) in order to move it to a lower position

dt.t: The investigation {it}lifted the lid on{/it} corruption in the company.

dt: {bc}to exercise by lifting heavy objects (such as barbells) in order to become stronger

dt.t: He has been {it}lifting weights{/it} for exercise.

shortdef: to exercise by lifting heavy objects (such as barbells) in order to become stronger

dt: {bc}a lift in weight lifting in which the weight is lifted from the floor to hip level

shortdef: a lift in weight lifting in which the weight is lifted from the floor to hip level
